Section on Doctrinal Interpretation 1: Zhu Shixing, Zhi Xiao, and Long
Zhu Shixing, a native of Yingchuan, had a straightforward character and could not be swayed by persuasion.
From a young age, he had lofty insights and was detached from worldly affairs. After going forth, he specialized in the study of scriptures.

In the past, during the time of Emperor Ling of the Han Dynasty, Zhu Foshuo translated the Sutra of Practicing the Way, which was an old version of the Small Treatise. The text was concise, and the meaning was not complete.
Shixing once lectured on the Sutra of Practicing the Way in Luoyang, and he felt that the literary style was hidden and the meaning was not perfect. He often sighed and said:
This sutra is the essence of the Mahayana, but the translation does not fully convey the principle.
He vowed to give up his life and seek the complete version from afar. Finally, in the fifth year of Ganlu of the Wei Dynasty, he left Yongzhou and crossed the Taklamakan Desert to the west.
When he arrived in Khotan, he indeed obtained the correct Sanskrit text in ninety chapters, and sent his disciple Butunadana, meaning Dharmaraja,
to return to Luoyang with the Sanskrit scriptures.
Before they left, the various Hinayana schools in Khotan finally reported to the king, saying:
The monks from China want to confuse the orthodox scriptures with the texts of the Brahmins.
If the king, as the lord of the land, does not stop them, he will cut off the great Dharma, leaving China deaf and blind. This is the king's fault.
The king then did not allow them to take the scriptures.
Shixing deeply felt pain in his heart, so he requested to burn the scriptures as proof, and the king agreed.
Then, he piled firewood in front of the palace and set it on fire.
Shixing faced the fire and vowed:
If the great Dharma is to spread to China, the scriptures should not burn. If there is no protection, what can be done?

Having said this, he threw the sutra into the fire, and the fire immediately went out, not damaging a single word. The leather pages were as they were before. The great assembly was amazed and served him, all praising its spiritual response.
He was then able to send it to Cang Hengshui Nan Temple in Chenliu.
At that time, Zhu Shulan, a layman from Henan, was originally from India. His father's generation took refuge and lived in Henan.
Shulan enjoyed hunting when young, but later he almost died and experienced the consequences of his karma.
He then changed his ways, focused his mind, deeply revered the true Dharma, and extensively studied various languages, being good at Sanskrit and Chinese.

There was also a monk named Wuluocha from the Western Regions, who was knowledgeable in ancient matters and had studied extensively. He then held the Sanskrit text in his hands, and Shulan translated it into Chinese, calling it the Shining Prajnaparamita.
The old leather pages are now in Yuzhang.
In the second year of Tai'an, Zhi Xiaolong obtained it from Shulan and copied the five parts at one time, collating them to form a definitive version.
At that time, there were no chapter titles. The old version was written on fourteen bolts of silk, totaling twenty scrolls.
Shixing eventually passed away in Khotan at the age of eighty.
Following the Western method, he was cremated. When the firewood was exhausted and the fire went out, the corpse was still intact. The crowd was amazed and chanted:
If he truly attained the Way, the Dharma should be destroyed.
With a sound, it shattered and scattered. They then collected the bones and built a stupa.
Later, his disciple Fayi came from that country and personally transmitted this matter. Therefore, Sun Chuo's Treatise on the True and Semblance Dharma says:
Shixing scattered his body in Khotan.
This is what it refers to.
Zhi Xiaolong, a native of Huaiyang,
was respected from a young age for his elegant demeanor. Moreover, his spiritual appearance was outstanding, and his lofty discussions were appropriate for the times.
He always studied and savored the Small Treatise and regarded it as the essence of the Dharma.
Ruan Zhan of Chenliu and Yu Yi of Yejun both formed friendships with him, and people of the time called them the Eight Talents.
Sometimes they teased him, saying:

When the great Jin Dynasty flourished, the world became its home. Why don't the Å›ramaá¹‡as keep their hair and skin intact, remove their kaá¹£Äya robes, abandon their Hu clothing, and wear silk and brocade?
Lu replied:
Embracing the One, I roam freely; only in stillness can I attain sincerity.
Shaving the head and damaging the appearance, changing clothes and altering the form, they consider it an insult to me, I discard it as glory to them.
Therefore, having no mind for nobility, I become more noble.
Having no mind for sufficiency, I become more sufficient.
His quick wit and timely eloquence were all of this kind.
At that time, Zhu Shulan first translated the Guangming Jing, and Lu, who had long enjoyed the formless, obtained it and read it for more than ten days, then began lecturing on it.
Later, it is unknown where he ended up.
Sun Chuo wrote a eulogy for him, saying:
Small squares are easy to imitate, but great objects are difficult to emulate. The majestic and virtuous Xiaolong surpasses in loftiness and vastness.
All things compete to take refuge, people think of emulating and looking up to him. The clouds and springs are vast, and the fragrance of orchids and the sound of cranes spread far.
Kang Senghui Kang Senghui was originally from the Western Regions, but was born in Chang'an.

Although he had the appearance of a barbarian, he spoke fluent Chinese. His demeanor was dignified and correct, and his aspirations were vast and profound. He recited the two PrajÃ±ÄpÄramitÄ sÅ«tras, namely the large and small versions.
In the time of Emperor Cheng of the Jin dynasty, he crossed the Yangtze River together with Kang Fachang, Zhi Mindu, and others.
Fachang also had talent and thought, and was good at correspondence. He wrote the Treatise on the Origins of People and Things, and others.
Fachang always carried a whisk in his hand. Whenever he met famous guests, they would engage in pure conversation until the end of the day.
Yu Yuangu said to Fachang:
Why do you always have this whisk?
Fachang said:
The frugal do not take, the greedy do not give, so it can always be there.
Min Du was also wise and had a reputation, and wrote a Record of Translated Sutras which is circulated in the world today.
Yuan, although his virtue surpassed Chang and Du, still distinguished himself by living simply, always supporting himself by begging, and people did not recognize him.

Later, while on a begging round, he encountered Yin Hao of Chen Jun. Hao first asked about the profound principles of the Buddhist scriptures, and then debated the meaning of nature and emotion in secular books. From noon until dusk, Hao was unable to defeat him, and from then on changed his views.
Wang Mao Hong of Langya joked about his high nose and deep eyes, and Yuan said:
The nose is the mountain of the face, and the eyes are the abyss of the face. If the mountain is not high, it is not spiritual. If the abyss is not deep, it is not clear.
People of the time considered it a good answer.
Later, he established a temple in Yuzhang Mountain, several tens of miles away from the town.
Following the river and mountains, the forests and bamboo are lush, and famous monks and excellent masters gather like a group.
Because the Sutra on Upholding the Mind has profound and distant emptiness, he especially lectured on it. Students of learning come and go, filling the place.
Later, he passed away in the temple.

Zhu Fayu was a person from Hejian. He was upright and had a broad mind. He was good at external studies when young and proficient in Buddhist principles when older. Scholars in robes all followed him for advice.

At that time, his disciples were all accomplished in worldly classics but not yet proficient in Buddhist principles. Fayu then, together with Kang Falang and others, used events and numbers in the sutras to match and correspond with external books, creating examples for generating understanding, calling it matching principles.
Then, Bibofu, Xiangtan, and others.
Also debated the matching principles to instruct their disciples.
Fayu's style was relaxed and he was good at the pivot of change.
He lectured on external classics and Buddhist sutras alternately.
Together with Dao'an and Fatai, they often discussed and resolved doubts, fully understanding the essentials of the sutras.
Later, he established a temple in Gaoyi, with over a hundred monks, tirelessly guiding and inspiring them.
Ya's disciple Tanying inherited his teacher's teachings and was good at debate.
He was respected by Prince Shi Xuan of the pseudo Zhao dynasty.
Kang Falang of Kang Falang was from Zhongshan. He left home at a young age and was good at observing precepts.
Once, while reading a sutra, he saw the place of the twin trees and Deer Park, and sighed deeply, saying:
Since I have not met the Sage, how can I not see the place where the Sage was?
Thus, he vowed to go to India, looking up to the remaining traces.
He then set out with four fellow students from Zhangye, crossing the desert to the west.

After traveling for three days, the road was cut off and there were no human traces. Suddenly, they saw an old temple by the side of the road, with weeds taller than a person. There were two dilapidated rooms, each with a person. One person was reciting sutras, and the other had dysentery. The two were in neighboring rooms, not taking care of each other. Excrement and urine were everywhere, and the entire room was foul-smelling.
Lang said to his followers:
Leaving home and practicing the Way is the same path. We consider the Dharma as our relatives. If we don't see each other, it's fine. How can we see and abandon each other?
Lang then stayed for six days to wash and make offerings.
On the seventh day, he saw that the room was filled with fragrant flowers. He realized that the person was a divine being.
He then said to Lang:
The person in the neighboring room is my teacher. He has attained the stage of no more learning. You can go and pay respects to him.
Lang went to pay respects and said to Lang:
You are truly kindred. You should all enter the Way. There is no need to travel far to other countries. It will not benefit you in your practice.
You should rely on your own power to practice the Way and not miss the right time.
But your accomplishments are still small and not yet complete, and you have not attained your wish. You should return to the country of China and become a great Dharma master.
Then the four people did not go west again, but stayed there to concentrate on practicing the Way.
Only Lang traveled to various countries to study the scriptures and treatises.
Later, he returned to Zhongshan, with hundreds of disciples, lecturing on the Dharma.
Later, it is unknown where he ended up.
Sun Chuo wrote a eulogy for him, saying:
There are also people who say that jade does not hide flaws. Master Lang was bright and could conceal his brilliance.
Respecting the end and being careful at the beginning, investigating the subtle and discerning the chapters, how to attain verification, like ice on firm ground, treading on frost.
Lang's disciple Ling Shao, originally from Yanmen, with the surname LÃ¼, was a hunter in his youth, but later developed the aspiration to leave home and served Lang as his teacher.
He was diligent in learning and was especially good at meditation and counting. Whenever he entered concentration, he would sometimes not arise for several days.
Later, he moved to Mount Liushui, where he carved out a cave to sit in meditation.
After Lang's death, they carved a wooden statue of him and worshipped it morning and evening.
Sun Chuo's Discourse on the Correct and the Counterfeit says:
LÃ¼ Shao concentrated his spirit at Mount Zhongnan.
This refers to him.
Zhu Facheng, whose origins are unknown,
was a prodigy from a young age, with extraordinary insight surpassing others. He became a novice under Zhu Faxing and had a pure and lofty character. Faxing highly praised him.

Since Faxing's teachings spread in Guanzhong, he also had abundant wealth. At that time, a prominent family in Chang'an wanted to follow the great Dharma. They tested Faxing's virtue and falsely went to him for twenty million coins in an emergency.
Before Faxing could reply, Cheng, who was thirteen years old, was by his teacher's side and said:
The master has already agreed.
After the guest left, Cheng said:
Judging from this person's appearance, he is not really seeking money, but is probably observing what kind of virtue the upÄdhyÄya has.
Hu said:
I also think so.
The next day, the guest led his entire clan of over a hundred people to Hu to request the precepts, apologizing for seeking money. Thus, the names of the teacher and disciple spread far and wide.
Later, Seng rode west to Dunhuang, established a temple, and attracted students. He forgot himself for the sake of the Way, teaching without weariness.
Causing even the wolves to change their hearts, and the barbarians to know propriety, the great transformation proceeded westward, and this was due to Seng's power.
Later, he passed away in his residence.
Sun Chuo's Discourse on the Virtuous in the Way compared Seng to Wang Junchong. The discourse said:
Fasheng and Anfeng had the insight to understand the mechanism of things from an early age. Although their conduct differed as laypeople and monastics, they could be compared as neighbors.
The noble person Ji Yong wrote a eulogy and biography for him.
His fellow students, Zhu Faxiang and Zhu Facu, both lived in the mountains and were known for their integrity in the world.
Zhu Qian, styled Fashin, was from a Wang family in Langya. He was the younger brother of Wang Dun, the Marquis of Wuchang Commandery.
At the age of eighteen, he left home and followed Liu Yuanshen of Zhongzhou as his teacher.
Liu Yuanshen had already gained a reputation for talent and understanding, so Sun Chuo praised him, saying:
His spirit is lofty and empty, his mind is dark and profound. Who can embody it? In my Liu Gong.
His discussions can be ornate, his illumination is enough to enlighten the ignorant. Within his bosom, it is always vast and open.

After Qian followed him, he cut off worldly affairs, valued the foundation, and focused on learning. He promoted subtle teachings and his reputation spread in the Western Capital. His demeanor and appearance were majestic.

At the age of twenty-four, he lectured on the Lotus Sutra and the Great Perfection of Wisdom Sutra. He had a deep understanding and was also good at speaking, so those who came to listen to his teachings were always over five hundred people.
In the beginning of the Yongjia era of the Jin dynasty, he crossed the river to avoid the chaos.
The founding emperor, the founding ancestor Mingdi, the chancellor Wang Mao, and the general Yu Yuanguan all admired his virtue and respected him as a friend.
During the Jianwu and Taiping eras, Qian often wore wooden clogs inside the palace. At that time, people all considered him an extraordinary person, because of his weighty virtue.
When the founding emperor and the founding ancestor passed away, Wang and Yu also died. He then hid in Mount Shem to avoid the world.
Those who followed him to inquire about the Way again gathered at the mountain gate.
Qian leisurely lectured for more than thirty years, sometimes on the Vaipulya sutras and sometimes on Laozi and Zhuangzi.
Those who devoted themselves to him all became well-versed in both internal and external matters.

Emperor Ai admired and respected the Buddha's teachings, and frequently sent two envoys to earnestly invite [Zhizhe]. Zhizhe temporarily visited the palace due to the heaviness of the imperial decree. He then opened a lecture on the MahÄprajÃ±ÄpÄramitÄ SÅ«tra at the imperial court. At that time, Emperor Jianwen served as the prime minister, and the court and the country considered him to be a paragon of virtue. Since Zhizhe was the leader of both monks and laypeople, and also a friend of the previous emperor, he was respected and revered even more than usual. Until the emperor ascended the throne, his devout worship became even more sincere.
Zhizhe once met Liu Dan of the Pei state at Emperor Jianwen's place. Dan teased him, saying:
Why does the Daoist roam the vermilion gate?
Zhizhe said:
You yourself see it as a vermilion gate, but I see it as a thatched gate.

He Chuzhi, the Minister of Works, had a noble character and pure conduct, and deeply believed in the scriptures. He always revered [Zhizhe] even more. He followed [Zhizhe] with the respect of a teacher and student, frequently inviting him and holding Dharma assemblies many times.

Although Qian followed the movement back and forth, he always felt unhappy. He then requested to return to Mount Yang in Shan, fulfilling his original intention. He then roamed the forests and hills to spend the rest of his life.
Zhi Dun sent a messenger to buy a small ridge on the side of Mount Yang, wanting to make it a secluded place. Qian replied:
If you want to come, I will give it to you. How can I hear that Zuoqiu Ming and Boyi Fazu bought a mountain to hide?
Later, Dun wrote a letter to a monk from Goguryeo, saying:
The Venerable Zhu Fasheng is a disciple of Liu Gong from the Central Plains. He is upright in character and virtue, and is the leader of both monks and laypeople.

He is now on Mount Yang in Shan County, leading like-minded companions to discuss the Way and expound the principles, living in lofty seclusion, praised far and near.
In the second year of Ningkang in the Jin dynasty, he died in the mountain lodge at the age of eighty-nine.
The illustrious Emperor Xiaowu issued an edict, saying:
Master Shen's understanding of principles was profound and far-reaching, his demeanor was pure and honest. He abandoned the glory of a prime minister and took on the simple robes of a monk.
Dwelling in the mountains, detached from worldly affairs, he was diligent and persevering. We relied on him to spread the Dharma and benefit sentient beings.
His sudden passing weighs heavily on my mind.
I will bestow ten thousand coins and send them by fast horse.
Sun Chuo compared Shen to Liu Berun, saying in his discussion:
Master Shen's conduct and learning were profound and weighty, with a vast and lofty mind;
Liu Ling indulged in unrestrained dissipation, considering the universe to be small.
Although Liu could not match Shen in the pursuit of lofty seclusion, they were the same in the essence of vastness.

At that time, there was also Zhu Fanyou on Mount Yang. His aspirations and conduct were firm and correct, and he had extensive knowledge of various scriptures. He once studied the Abhidharma with Shen and recited it after one night.
Shen said:
Reciting the scriptures is called 'chanting' by the ancients. If the Buddha were to appear again in the Great Jin dynasty, you would certainly be one of the five hundred disciples.
At the age of twenty-four, he was already able to lecture.
Later, he established Tai Temple south of the city of Shan County.

Once he encountered Kang Xin, who considered his calligraphy to surpass Fashi's. They each wrote in the cursive style of Ouyang Xun. Bystanders secretly regarded it as a treasure, but no one could tell them apart.
He also copied many scriptures, which were highly valued.

8 Zhiduoluo Zhidun, styled Daolin, was originally surnamed Guan, a person from Chenliu, or said to be from Linlu, Hedong.
He had a divine nature since childhood, and was exceptionally intelligent.
When he first arrived in the capital, Taiyuan Wang Meng greatly respected him, saying:
His achievements in subtle matters are no less than Fu Xi.
Chen Jun Yin Rong once interacted with Wei Jie, praising his extraordinary spirit and insight, and said no one in the younger generation could match him.
When he saw Zhidun, he sighed in admiration, thinking he was seeing such a person again.
His family had served the Buddha for generations, and he early awakened to the principles of the extraordinary truth.

He secluded himself on Mount Yuhang, deeply contemplating the chapter on practice, and thoroughly understanding the sutra on the seal of wisdom. He stood out alone, attaining it from the mind of heaven.

At the age of twenty-five, he left home. Whenever he attended lectures, he was good at identifying the main points, but sometimes he would miss some phrases. At that time, those who adhered to the text looked down upon him.
Xie An heard of this and praised him, saying:
This is like Jiufang Yin's evaluation of horses, omitting the color and taking only the swiftness.

Wang Qia, Liu Hui, Yin Hao, Xu Xun, Xi Chao, Sun Shu, Huan Yanzhi, Wang Jingren, He Cidao, Wang Wenduo, Xie Changxia, Yuan Yanbo, and others, all famous figures of the time, were all close friends outside the dust.
Dun was once at Baima Temple.
With Liu Xizhi and others.
Discussing the Xiaoyao Chapter of Zhuangzi, he said:
Each person's nature is what makes them happy.
Dun said:
No, Jie and Zhi consider harming others to be their nature. If following one's nature is considered right, then they would also be happy.
Then he retired and wrote a commentary on the Xiaoyao chapter.
The old scholars of the Confucian school all marveled at it.
Later, he returned to Wu and established Zhishan Temple.
In the evening, he wanted to enter Shan, Xie An was in Wuxing, and he wrote a letter to Du saying:
Thinking of you day after day, counting the days in longing, I know you want to return to Shan to govern yourself, and I am greatly disappointed.
Life is like a temporary stay, the events of the past that I enjoyed with you are almost all gone.
All day long I am gloomy, encountering things with sadness, only waiting for you to come to dispel it with conversation, one day is like a thousand years.

This mountainous prefecture is quiet and still, just barely able to nurture illness, the situation is no different from Shan, but the medicine and care are different, you must think of this condition and fulfill your accumulated thoughts.
Wang Xizhi was then in Kuaiji, he had long heard of Du's name.
He did not believe it, and said to people:
What is the use of talking about the qi of one who has gone?
Later, after Du returned to Shan, he passed through the prefecture, and Wang deliberately visited Du to observe his demeanor.
When he arrived, Wang said to Du:
Can I hear the chapter on carefree wandering?
Dun then wrote several thousand words, highlighting new principles, with amazing talent and eloquence.
The king then unbuttoned his robe, untied his belt, and lingered unable to leave.
He further invited him to stay at Lingjia Temple, intending to stay close to him.
Soon after, he again left his traces in Mount Shan, establishing a temple on Xiao Ling of Wozhou to practice the Way. Over a hundred monks constantly followed to receive teachings.
Sometimes there were those who fell, so Dun wrote a Seat Right Inscription to encourage them.
It said:
Strive, strive! The ultimate Way is not far. Why linger?
The weak lose the marvelous.
In the vast three realms, long drifting, external worries gather, the mind internally roams.
Pursuing with reverence and thirst, forgetting fatigue in far-off places, a person's life is like a dew drop.
My body is not me, who is it that uses it? The enlightened understand virtue, knowing that comfort must end in danger.
He was tranquil and lofty, purifying the pond of Chan practice, carefully guarding the bright precepts, and elegantly enjoying the profound rules.
He calmed his mind in the Way of the gods, and his will was directed towards non-action. He illuminated the three obstructions and melted away the six faults.
Emptiness was the same as the five aggregates, and the four limbs were open and empty. It was not a finger pointing to the moon, but rather a transcendence beyond all conceptualization.
After the wonderful enlightenment was presented, he furthered his understanding. He turned and adapted to the changing world, going beyond this and not thinking or discussing it.
He earnestly followed the father of enlightenment, whose will was directed towards the infant.

At that time, people discussed how Fu's talent was suitable for praising the sutras, but his purity and detachment from the world went against the way of universal salvation. Fu then wrote the Discourse on Releasing the Ignorance.
Later, he moved to Mount Shicheng and established Qiguang Temple.
He sat in meditation at the mountain gate, roamed in the garden of Chan practice, ate wood-flavored food, drank from the stream, and aspired to be free from birth and death.

All the listeners thought that if they thoroughly understood his meaning, they could make him explain it, but after two or three times, they became confused.

When Emperor Ai of the Jin Dynasty ascended the throne, he frequently sent two envoys to invite him to come to the capital. The black-robed monks and white-robed laypeople revered him, and the court and the common people were delighted and followed him.

Xi Chao asked Xie An:
How does Master Lin's discussion compare to that of Aji Zhongsan?
An said:
Aji barely manages to keep up.
He asked again:
How about Yin Hao?
An said:

His discussions are smooth and eloquent, but I'm afraid Yin's composition is inferior. Xi Chao's profound understanding and direct insight into the source are truly admirable. Hao really has some shame.
Xi Chao later wrote in a letter to his close friends:
Master Lin's spiritual understanding is profound and his enlightenment is unique.
In fact, for hundreds of years, he alone has upheld the great Dharma and ensured that the truth is not cut off.
Dun stayed in the capital for nearly three years, then returned to the eastern mountains.
He wrote a letter of farewell, saying:
Dun bows his head and says:
I dare to seek the wind beyond the world with my lack of talent, but I have not been able to whip up the rear, using the spiritual transformation.
The meaning of Å›ramaá¹‡as is that the Dharma comes from the Buddha's sages. Carving simplicity and returning to the origin, cutting off desires and returning to the essence.
Wandering in the realm of emptiness and mystery, guarding the principles of the inner sage, wearing the chastity of the five precepts, and observing the transformation of the outer king.
Harmonizing with the music of no sound, taking self-realization as harmony.ğŸ”½Deeply cultivating the filial piety of compassion, not harming any living creature;
Feeling the grief of no resentment, forever mourning the unkind.
Holding the obedience of no sign, preventing future lives from afar;
Drinking the standard of no position, not regretting even in extreme circumstances.

Therefore, wise kings, in the weight of governing the southern side, all admire its style, rest in its easy track, explore its conforming mind, andç•¥ its formal respect, thus causing it to be renewed through the ages.

Your Majesty, Heaven bestows you with sagely virtue, you elegantly enjoy without tiring, you roam in the numinous model, forgetting to ride as the sun sets, you can be said to strike the bell and drum at dawn, your voice shaking the world.
The clear wind has already spread, none are not extremely fortunate.

Above, I wish Your Majesty will equal the two polarities in longevity, widely spread the supreme transformation, discard the demon lies of Chen Xin, seek the grand discussion of Qiu Dao, cut off the small path leading to mud, and gallop the great chariot on the level road.
If so, Mount Tai will not be lustful on the journey of the Ji clan, attaining oneness to become spiritual;
The king will not offer sacrifices without the perfect hill, attaining oneness to be eternally upright.

If the upright and spiritual each have their own, and humans and spirits forget each other, the ruler is a ruler, and those below have no one to rely on. The spirits are spirits, and curses do not add spiritual power. Profound virtue is universally bestowed, and the people receive mysterious blessings. Vast and vast, it becomes a dwelling of auspiciousness.
Vast and vast, the great Jin becomes the realm of primordial flourishing.

Always without action, yet the myriad things return to the root. Upholding the great image, the world goes of its own accord. The state's penal code for killing has its own offices. If it is life and not kindness, then the rewarded obtain it on their own.
If it is killing and not anger, then the punished receive their punishment on their own.
Vastly using public instruments to satisfy the spiritual mind, holding the scales to exhaust the mysterious extent.
What is called How can Heaven speak? The four seasons proceed.

I, a poor Daoist, have been wandering in the eastern mountains, different from the world's glory. Eating vegetables and wild grains, washing my mouth in the flowing water, wearing coarse clothes all my life, never looking up at the imperial steps.
Not understanding the subtle radiance of the sun and moon, I was foolishly wrapped in coarse clothes, frequently receiving clear edicts to go to the capital. I hesitated, not knowing what to do.
Since arriving in the celestial court, I have repeatedly been summoned to audience, treated with hospitality, and instructed with subtle words.

Each time I am ashamed that my talent is not outstanding, and my understanding does not grasp the new, not enough to respond to the profound model, truly blocking sight and hearing, shrinking in the presence of attendants, sweating on the seat.
In the past, the four elders went to Han, and Gan Mu served Wei. They all had times for leaving and entering, and their silence and speech were appropriate.

Now, my virtue is not that of a former person, and my movements and stillness are out of tune. Wandering in the imperial court, speaking boldly by the emperor's side, exhausted and unsupported, how can I be of service?
Moreover, the years have passed quickly, and I feel such sighs. Moreover, my like-minded friends are far away, and my acquaintances are scattered. Looking east, who can be without thoughts?
I hope Your Majesty will grant me permission to return to the forest and raise birds as I did before. I am deeply grateful for your kindness.
I respectfully present this board to inform you of my humble opinion. I will provision myself and await your compassionate decree.
The emperor immediately approved it and provided generous supplies for his departure. At that time, famous people all saw him off at the garrison.
Cai Zishu arrived first and sat near Dun. Xie Wan arrived later and happened to move to Cai's seat.
When Cai returned, he picked up Xie's seat cushion and threw it on the ground. Xie did not take it to heart.
He was admired by the sages of the time like this.
Later, he hid in Mount Shan and devoted his life to the forest.
Someone once gave a horse to Dun, and Dun loved and raised it. At that time, there were those who criticized him, and Dun said:
I love its divine speed and just keep it.
Later, someone gave him a crane, and Dun said to the crane:
This is a creature that soars in the heavens, how can it be an amusement for the ears and eyes?
So he released it.
When Ge Xuan was young, he once discussed the classification of creatures with his teacher, saying that using a chicken egg does not constitute killing, and the teacher could not be convinced.

The teacher soon died, and suddenly appeared, throwing an egg on the ground, the shell broke and the chick walked away, and in a moment both disappeared. Ge Xuan was then enlightened, and from then on he ate vegetarian food for the rest of his life.
Ge Xuan first lived in Yuyuan Mountain, and even on the day of his death he returned to the mountain. Someone asked him the reason.
He replied:
Xie An came to see me several times in the past, and each time he stayed for several tens of days. Now, whenever I encounter something or raise my eyes, I cannot help but think of him.

Later, when he was seriously ill, he moved back to the mountain. On the fourth day of the fourth month of the intercalary month in the first year of Taihe in the Jin dynasty, he died at the age of fifty-three.
He was buried in the mountain, and his tomb still exists.
Some say he died in Shan, but this is not known for sure.
Xie Chao wrote a preface and biography for him, Yuan Hong wrote an inscription and eulogy for him, and Zhou Tanbao wrote a eulogy for him.
Sun Chuo's Discourse on the Virtuous in the Way compares him to Zichang, saying:
Zhi Dun and Xiang Xiu both admired Zhuangzi and Laozi.
The two masters were from different times, but their love for the profound was the same.
Another Discourse on the Way says:
Zhi Daolin.
His clear understanding and compliant nature did not confront things.
The profound way is vast and inclusive, following the spirit and emotions.
This is why the distant stream returns to the source, but the confused ones have yet to awaken.
Later, the noble man Dai Kui passed by Dun's tomb and sighed:
The sound of virtue has not yet faded, yet the tomb has become overgrown with trees. I hope the divine principles will continue on, not ending together with the change of qi.
Dun had a classmate named Faqian who was skilled in the principles and understood the profound, passing away before Dun.
Dun sighed and said:
In the past, the craftsman Shi was rejected by the people of Ying, and Ya Sheng stopped playing the strings for Zhong Zi. Pushing oneself to seek others, it is truly not in vain.
Since the precious agreement has been hidden, no one appreciates my words. My heart is full of knots, and I will die.
He then wrote the Chapter on Cutting Through Delusion, finishing it before his death, and passed away as he put down the brush.
In total, Dun's literary works and collections amounted to ten scrolls, which circulated widely in the world.
At that time, there was also Zhu Fayang in the East, whose wisdom and understanding were well-known, and he was respected by Wang Tan.
After his death, he was still seen visiting the king, exhorting him with his practice.
Yu Falang Yu Falang, a person from Gaoyang, had extraordinary conduct from a young age.
At fifteen, he left home and made diligence his occupation. He recited scriptures day and night, seeking the Dharma and inquiring about the Way, always at the forefront of the group.
By the time he was of age, his spiritual energy was outstanding. His Way shook the three rivers, and his fame spread far and wide.
He loved mountains and springs, often staying in mountain caves.

Once during the winter months, when the snow and ice were severe, a tiger came into the hermitage. Lan's expression was undisturbed, and the tiger was also very docile. It stayed until the next morning when the snow stopped and then left.
The mountain spirits would often come to receive the Dharma. His virtue extended to the spirits, and it was of this kind.

Later, hearing that the mountains and waters of Jiangdong, and especially Yan county, were extraordinary, he slowly traveled east to Ou, gazing at Mount Gou and Mount Sheng from afar. He stayed at the foot of Mount Shicheng, which is now Yuanhua Temple.
At that time, people compared his lofty demeanor to that of Yu Yuanguan, and Sun Chuo's Discourse on the Virtuous in the Way compared him to Ruan Sizong. The discourse says:
Master Lan abandoned his body, lofty and sublime, almost a sage.
Ruan Pibing was arrogant and unique, also a match for Lan.
After staying in Yan for a short time, he suddenly sighed and said:
Although the great Dharma has flourished, the scriptures are often incomplete. If I could hear the perfect teachings just once, I would be willing to die tonight.
He then traveled far to the Western Regions, wishing to seek out different teachings. When he reached Jiaozhou, he encountered illness and passed away in Xianglin.
The monk Zhizun wrote a eulogy for the statue:
The Yu clan transcends the world, comprehending the profound principles. They gracefully reclusive in mountains and marshes, befriending tigers and rhinos.
A separate biography says:
Lan also caused a dried spring to flow with water.
His story is the same as that of Zhu Fahu.
It is not known for certain.

There were also Zhu Faxiang, Zhi Fayan, and Yu Fadao, who were contemporaries and equals of Lan. Faxiang was known for his extensive knowledge, Fayan was famous for his talent and eloquence, and Fadao was renowned for his doctrinal understanding.
Yu Fadeng Yu Fadeng, not known from which place.

He became a disciple of Lan Gong, deeply contemplating and independently generating insights, expressing himself uniquely. He was good at the Light Emitting and Lotus Sutras, and also inherited the teachings of Jiva, skillfully understanding medical methods.
Once, while begging for food and entering a host's house, he encountered a woman in a life-threatening situation, with many treatments failing to work. The whole family was in a flurry. Kai said:
This is easy to treat.

The host was just slaughtering a sheep, intending to perform a licentious sacrifice. Kai told him to first take some meat to make soup. After it was served, he used acupuncture based on the qi. In a moment, the baby came out wrapped in the sheep's placenta.
In the fifth year of Shengping, when Emperor Xiaozong fell ill, Kai examined his pulse and knew he would not recover. He refused to enter again. Empress Kangxian ordered:

The emperor is slightly unwell. Yesterday he called upon Gong to examine his pulse, but he reached the gate and would not go further, making various excuses. He should be arrested and sent to the Court of Judicial Review.
Soon after, the emperor passed away, and he was spared.
He returned to Shicheng in Shan and continued to repair Yuanhua Temple, later moving to Lingjiu Temple on Mount Bai.

He often debated with Zhi Daolin about the meaning of emptiness in form, and He Mo of Lujiang clarified and explained the difficulties, while Xi Chao of Gaoping proclaimed Lin's understanding, both of which circulated in the world.
Kai had a disciple named Fawei, who was clear-minded and had the ability to debate, so Sun Chuo wrote a eulogy for him, saying:
The Book of Changes says 'white feathers', the Book of Poetry praises 'plantain and water chestnut'.
Spotted like in a field, fragrant like stagnant water.
Yu and Wei are enlightened, and investigate far and wide.
Having purified their names, they have no shame in their hearts.
Kai once sent Wei to the capital, passing through Shanyin.
Zhi Dun was lecturing on the Small Treatise.
Kai told Wei:
When you arrive at Dao Lin's lecture, you should be at a certain chapter.
He instructed Wei to attack and question dozens of times, saying:
This is an old difficulty to resolve.

When Wei arrived at the prefecture, he happened to be at the time when Dun was lecturing, and it was indeed as Kai had said. They went back and forth many times, and Dun finally yielded. He then raised his voice and said:
Why do you still need to carry other people's luggage?
Therefore, the Eastern Mountain Record says:
Deep understanding, open thinking, forest discussion, knowledgeable record.

During the time of Emperor Ai, he was repeatedly summoned by imperial edict. He then lectured on the Guangming Jing in the capital. All those who had doubts about the old studies, none did not have them resolved through him. After the lecture was over, he declined and returned to Eastern Mountain.
The emperor sincerely admired his virtue and gave him money, silk, a sedan chair, and winter and summer clothes. Xie An and Wang Wenduo were all friendly with him.
Someone asked:
The Dharma Master is lofty, bright, and upright. Why does he carry medical skills in his mind?
He replied:

To illuminate the six perfections in order to eliminate the illness of the four demons, and to adjust the nine conditions in order to cure the illnesses of wind and cold, benefiting oneself and benefiting others, is this not good?
He died at the age of sixty at the mountain temple. Sun Chuo wrote a eulogy for him, saying:
His eloquence was expansive, and he propagated the teachings with various methods. This was the case with Master Kai!
Yu Daosui, a person from Dunhuang, lost his parents at an early age and was raised by his uncle. Daosui's filial piety and reverence were as if he were serving his own mother.
At the age of sixteen, he left home and became a disciple of Master Luan.

His academic achievements were lofty and bright, and he had a comprehensive understanding of both Chinese and foreign cultures. He was good at medicine and calligraphy, and had a thorough understanding of different customs. He was especially skilled in debate.
Master Hui often praised Daosui for his lofty simplicity and purity, having the style of an ancient person. If he did not have a square-shaped head, he would have been a great pillar of the Dharma.
Later, he crossed the river with Master Jian and was greatly respected by Xie Qiongdun.
He loved mountains and waters by nature, and often traveled to famous mountains in the east.
He did not care about slander or praise, and never let worldly matters interfere with his studies.
Later, when Lan went to the Western Regions, he died of illness in Jiaozhi at the age of thirty-one.
Xi Chao painted his portrait, and Zhi Dun wrote a eulogy, saying:
The outstanding monk, with penetrating understanding and pure principles,
Has a bright appearance like jade, and virtuous speech fragrant like orchids.
Sun Chuo compared Sui to Ruan Xian, and someone said:
Xian was criticized for having many followers, while Sui had the reputation of being pure and aloof. How can they be compared?
Sun Chuo said:
Although their traces have ups and downs, their lofty style is the same.
The Discourse on the Metaphysics of the Way says:
Recently, in Luoyang, there was Zhu Faxiang, whose eloquence was enjoyed by the people;
In the south of the Yangtze River, there was Yu Daosui, whose understanding was recognized by the superior class.
These were all seen and heard by the people of the time, not private praise by like-minded people.
Zhu Fachong, whose place of origin is unknown.

He entered the path at a young age and was known for his observance of precepts. Moreover, he was intelligent and loved learning, diligently studying scriptures and records, and was especially skilled in the teaching of the Lotus Sutra.

Once, he traveled to Lu Mountain in Xiangzhou. The mountain spirit transformed into a noblewoman, came to Chong to request precepts, and offered the mountain where she resided to be made into a temple. Chong lived there for a short time.
His teachings pervaded the land of Xiang.
Later, he returned to Mount Ge Xian in Shan, living in a thatched hut by a stream, delighting in meditation and wisdom. Learners from the eastern part of Ou vied to come and gather.

He met with the recluse Kong Chun Zhi of Lu State. Whenever they went on outings, they would stay overnight and forget to return home. They opened their hearts and minds to each other, considering each other as friends who had found resonance in their hearts.
Chong then sighed and said:
Thinking of more than thirty years outside of human society, I have not realized that old age is approaching.
Later, when Chun Zhi went on a separate journey, Chong sang:
The bright and clear qi is still in the mind's eye, the mountain and forest people go and do not return.
What can be said about such a person!
Chong later died in the mountains, and wrote a four-fascicle commentary on the Lotus Sutra.
At that time, on the eastern slope of Mount Yang in Yan, there was also Shi Daobao, whose original surname was Wang, and he was a person from Langya, the younger brother of Jin Xiangguo Dao.
At a young age, he had faith and understanding, and avoided the world, declining honors and wealth. Relatives and friends tried to stop him, but none could restrain him.
He bathed in fragrant hot water, and was about to shave his head, then he sang:
How can one know that the myriad-mile-long water originates from the initial trickle?
Later, he became known for his learning and conduct.
Zhu Fayi, whose place of origin is unknown.
At the age of thirteen, he met Shi Shen and asked:
Benevolence and righteousness are what a gentleman practices. Why did Confucius rarely speak of them?
Shen said:
Few people are able to practice them, therefore he rarely spoke of them.
Seeing that he was young but intelligent, he encouraged him to leave the household life.
Thus, he took refuge in the Dharma gate and studied under Seng.
He was well-versed in various scriptures, especially the Lotus Sutra.
Later, he took leave of Seng and went to the capital, where he further greatly opened lecture seats. Wang Dao and Kong Fu both respected him as a friend.
In the Xingning era of the Jin dynasty, he returned to Jiangzuo and stayed at Baoshan in Shinan, with over a hundred disciples studying under him.

In the second year of Xian'an, he suddenly fell ill with heart and stomach problems. He always contemplated Guanyin and dreamed that a person cut open his stomach and washed his intestines. When he woke up, the illness was cured.
Fu Liang often said:
My late father associated with Master Yi and often heard him talk about Guanyin's spiritual manifestations, which made everyone, young and old, feel awe.

In the third year of Ningkang of the Jin dynasty, Emperor Xiaowu sent envoys to invite him to come to the capital to lecture. He passed away in the capital in the fifth year of Taiyuan of the Jin dynasty at the age of seventy-four.
The emperor bought Xin'an Hill with 100,000 coins to build a tomb for him, and erected a three-story pagoda. Huiyi's disciple Tan Shuang built a temple at the tomb site and named it Xin'an Temple.
Later, when Emperor Xiaowu of the Song went south to attack the rebels, his imperial carriage stopped at this temple.
When he ascended the throne, he visited the Chan Hall again, expanded it, and renamed it Zhongxing.
Therefore, at the end of the Yuanjia era, a folk saying went:
A Son of Heaven will emerge from Qiantang.
This refers to the Chan Hall.
Therefore, the Chan Hall of Zhongxing still had the Dragon-Flying Palace, which is now Tian'an Temple.
Zhu Sengdu, whose surname was Wang and name was Xi, was also known as Xuanzong. He was from Dongguan.
Although he was orphaned at a young age, he had outstanding talent.
By the age of sixteen, his spirit was clear and outstanding, and he was extraordinary. His nature was gentle and harmonious, admired by the neighbors.
At that time, he lived alone with his mother, serving her with utmost filial piety.

He sought the daughter of Yang Deshen of the same prefecture, who was also from a family of officials and nobility. The daughter's name was Tiaohua, and she was upright and beautiful, and also good at classical literature. She was the same age as Du. On the day of the marriage proposal, they were engaged.
Before the wedding could take place, Tiaohua's mother passed away. Soon after, Tiaohua's father also passed away, and her stepmother also died.
Du then witnessed the impermanence of the generations and suddenly had an enlightenment. He therefore renounced secular life and became a monk, changing his name to Sengdu.
He distanced himself from worldly affairs and traveled to study.

After Tiaohua finished her mourning period, she thought to herself that as a woman, she had no way to stand on her own according to the principle of the three obediences, so she wrote a letter to Du, saying that one's hair and skin should not be harmed or defiled, and one's ancestral sacrifices should not be suddenly discontinued, and urging him to consider the teachings of the world and change his far-reaching aspirations, to shine his outstanding appearance in the prosperous and bright world, to bring distant blessings to the spirits of his ancestors, and to fulfill the wishes of his family members.
She also sent him five poems, one of which said:
The Great Way is boundless, and heaven and earth are long and enduring.
Huge rocks are difficult to dissolve, and mustard seeds are also hard to count.
A person's life in this world is fleeting, like passing through a window.
How can glory and wealth last long? They quickly wither and decay.
There is leftover poetry by the river, and in the evening I think of beating the drum.
Clear sounds can delight the ears, flavors can please the mouth, silk can adorn the body, and colorful crowns can illuminate the head.
Why do you insist on cutting your hair and harming your existence by indulging in emptiness?
I am not saying you are petty, but I want you to consider your descendants.
Du replied in a letter:
Serving a ruler to govern a single country is not as good as propagating the Way to benefit myriad states;
Relieving one's parents to form a single family is not as good as propagating the Way to save the three realms.
Not damaging one's hair and skin is just a minor saying in worldly matters.
But I am ashamed that my virtue is not far-reaching and I am unable to benefit all, and I feel remorse for this.
However, accumulating small mounds to form a mountain, I also hope to achieve greatness from small beginnings.
Moreover, wearing the kasaya robe, shaking the begging bowl, drinking clear streams, and chanting the Prajnaparamita Sutra.
Even if one were to wear the robes of a prince, enjoy the delicacies of the eight treasures, listen to the sounds of bells and chimes, and behold the brilliant colors, I would not be moved.
If one can deeply understand, then one will attain nirvana together.
Moreover, people's minds are different, just like their faces. Your dislike of the Way is like my lack of admiration for worldly affairs.
The Yang family, we have been separated for a long time!
The karmic connections of myriad generations have now ended!

The year is coming to an end, time does not wait for anyone. Those who study the Way should take reducing [attachment] as their goal. Those who live in the world should take seizing the moment as their task.
Your age and virtue are both flourishing. You should quickly pursue what you aspire to. Do not let the Way occupy your mind and sit idly by while youth passes.
He also wrote five poems in reply, the first one says:
The passage of time is relentless, the years and seasons pass by in a flash.
Even a huge rock will eventually be exhausted, how much more so a small amount of mustard seeds.
It is precisely because of the unceasing passing that it causes the lamentations by the riverside.
I have not heard of Rong Qishi, with his white hair, singing a clear song.
Cloth can keep one warm, who cares about fancy brocade?
Although this life may be said to be happy, how can one manage future lives?
Good and evil truly depend on oneself, how can one say one is concerned about others?
Since Du had a will that was not like a rock, it could not be turned back, and Tianshui was moved and awakened, and also gave rise to deep faith.

Du then devoted himself to the Buddha's teachings, studied various scriptures, and wrote the Return to the Meaning of Abhidharma, which is also circulated in the world. Later, it is unknown where he ended up.
